newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dlr/yen rise mostly normalisation of yen - Blinder.
newsitem.headline: Dlr/yen rise mostly normalisation of yen - Blinder.

text.p: The recent rise of the dollar against the yen is mostly a normalisation of an excessively strong yen and its negative impact on U.S. exports is not a major one, Alan Blinder, former Federal Reserve vice chairman, told Reuters Financial Television in an interview on Friday.
"The most important thing to remember is that the yen was way overvalued. Like 80 yen to a dollar. And most of (the dollar's rise) is just a snap back to normal," Blinder said.
He added that the dollar's movement against other currencies has not been that dramatic and in trade-weighted average terms, its movement has been farily modest.
"So it is a small negative for U.S. export performance but not a major one." he said.
Blinder, now a professor at Princeton University, also said the United States is very loath to get involved actively in exchange rate management.

"It does so occasionally, and who knows when they will again, as it is in the hands of the Treasury (Department), but it's something the U.S. does not like to do a lot." -- Tokyo Policy Desk +81-3-5473-3710
